lg.l: Often dreaming of days bygone
Kind memory brings back again
Pleasant summer days I once knew
On the Wairarapa Plain. Wairarapa Plain. A region north of Wellington, in the south of the North Island, which was first explored for settlement in 1841.
In those days my blood would circle
Freer, quicker in each vein,
When I turned my horse’s bridle
For the Wairarapa Plain.
Past the Hutt and Mungaroa, Hutt and Mungaroa. Travellers from Wellington to Wairarapa would journey up the Hutt River and then through the Mangaroa wetland.
Then the Rimutaka Rimutaka. The Remutaka Range divides Wellington from the Wairarapa. gain,
Breezy height that guards the passage
To the wide expanded Plain.
When at last I passed thy summit,
Heedless I of wind or rain,
I had clomb the mountain barrier,
Soon would reach the level Plain.
Down descending gazed I forward,
Looking onward to obtain
The first green and shining vista

Of the voiceless spreading Plain. Spreading Plain. Much of the Wairarapa plain near the Remutaka Range was covered in grass and scrub at the time of colonisation, which settlers replaced with introduced grass species to support the expanding pastoral economy.
One look across to where the Lake Lake. Lake Wairarapa is a large lake and wetland area near the Remutaka Range that drains into the sea on the southern coast of the North Island.
Sleeps quiet by the restless main,
And then at last—at last I’m bounding
O’er the long and sea-like Plain.
Sweet the birds sang in the green bush,
And my thirsty sense did drain
Its fill of life and health and sunshine,
In that summer on the Plain.
Happy days which only memory
Now can bring me back again;
They were transient, though through ages
Bathed in sunshine lies the Plain.
